CVE-2018-20150.summary: In WordPress before 4.9.9 and 5.x before 5.0.1, crafted URLs could trigger XSS for certain use cases involving plugins.

CVE-2018-10101.summary: Before WordPress 4.9.5, the URL validator assumed URLs with the hostname localhost were on the same host as the WordPress server.

CVE-2018-10100.summary: Before WordPress 4.9.5, the redirection URL for the login page was not validated or sanitized if forced to use HTTPS.

CVE-2018-10102.summary: Before WordPress 4.9.5, the version string was not escaped in the get_the_generator function, and could lead to XSS in a generator tag.

CVE-2016-4567.summary: Cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in flash/FlashMediaElement.as in MediaElement.js before 2.21.0, as used in WordPress before 4.5.2, allows remote attackers to inject arbitrary web script or HTML via an obfuscated form of the jsinitfunction parameter, as demonstrated by "jsinitfunctio%gn."

CVE-2016-4566.summary: Cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in plupload.flash.swf in Plupload before 2.1.9, as used in WordPress before 4.5.2, allows remote attackers to inject arbitrary web script or HTML via a Same-Origin Method Execution (SOME) attack.

CVE-2019-9787.summary: WordPress before 5.1.1 does not properly filter comment content, leading to Remote Code Execution by unauthenticated users in a default configuration. This occurs because CSRF protection is mishandled, and because Search Engine Optimization of A elements is performed incorrectly, leading to XSS. The XSS results in administrative access, which allows arbitrary changes to .php files. This is related to wp-admin/includes/ajax-actions.php and wp-includes/comment.php.

CVE-2018-20148.summary: In WordPress before 4.9.9 and 5.x before 5.0.1, contributors could conduct PHP object injection attacks via crafted metadata in a wp.getMediaItem XMLRPC call. This is caused by mishandling of serialized data at phar:// URLs in the wp_get_attachment_thumb_file function in wp-includes/post.php.

CVE-2018-5776.summary: WordPress before 4.9.2 has XSS in the Flash fallback files in MediaElement (under wp-includes/js/mediaelement).

CVE-2018-20152.summary: In WordPress before 4.9.9 and 5.x before 5.0.1, authors could bypass intended restrictions on post types via crafted input.

CVE-2018-20149.summary: In WordPress before 4.9.9 and 5.x before 5.0.1, when the Apache HTTP Server is used, authors could upload crafted files that bypass intended MIME type restrictions, leading to XSS, as demonstrated by a .jpg file without JPEG data.

CVE-2019-8942.summary: WordPress before 4.9.9 and 5.x before 5.0.1 allows remote code execution because an _wp_attached_file Post Meta entry can be changed to an arbitrary string, such as one ending with a .jpg?file.php substring. An attacker with author privileges can execute arbitrary code by uploading a crafted image containing PHP code in the Exif metadata. Exploitation can leverage CVE-2019-8943.

CVE-2018-12895.summary: WordPress through 4.9.6 allows Author users to execute arbitrary code by leveraging directory traversal in the wp-admin/post.php thumb parameter, which is passed to the PHP unlink function and can delete the wp-config.php file. This is related to missing filename validation in the wp-includes/post.php wp_delete_attachment function. The attacker must have capabilities for files and posts that are normally available only to the Author, Editor, and Administrator roles. The attack methodology is to delete wp-config.php and then launch a new installation process to increase the attacker's privileges.

CVE-2018-20153.summary: In WordPress before 4.9.9 and 5.x before 5.0.1, contributors could modify new comments made by users with greater privileges, possibly causing XSS.

CVE-2017-1000600.summary: WordPress version <4.9 contains a CWE-20 Input Validation vulnerability in thumbnail processing that can result in remote code execution. This attack appears to be exploitable via thumbnail upload by an authenticated user and may require additional plugins in order to be exploited however this has not been confirmed at this time. This issue appears to have been partially, but not completely fixed in WordPress 4.9

CVE-2018-20147.summary: In WordPress before 4.9.9 and 5.x before 5.0.1, authors could modify metadata to bypass intended restrictions on deleting files.

CVE-2017-14719.summary: Before version 4.8.2, WordPress was vulnerable to a directory traversal attack during unzip operations in the ZipArchive and PclZip components.

CVE-2018-20151.summary: In WordPress before 4.9.9 and 5.x before 5.0.1, the user-activation page could be read by a search engine's web crawler if an unusual configuration were chosen. The search engine could then index and display a user's e-mail address and (rarely) the password that was generated by default.

About Us

About Us

Why Us?

We are a highly transparent and customer centric company. Customer satisfaction is paramount to our objectives and we pride ourselves for creating this goodwill and maintaining it over 33-years. Read More

Production Facilities

Our state-of-the-art mill is located at the very epicenter of Haryana’s rice growing belt. It’s location on the main highway connecting the region is highly advantageous for logistics efficiency. Read More

Core Values

Being one of India’s most respected and pioneering rice sellers and producers, United Exports operates through a system of core philosophies and values that have kept it going for more than 30 years Read More

KEY PEOPLE

KEY PEOPLE

Harish Narang

Chairman & Managing Director


Mr. Harish Narang is the founder and visionary behind United Exports. He started the company in 1983 as a small trading firm and has slowly built it in to a fully integrated, highly respected milling enterprise. Mr. Narang’s focus on quality and transparency has helped create solid goodwill for UE in both, India and abroad.

Sudhanshu Narang

Chief Operating Officer

Mr. Sudhanshu Narang graduated from the University of Cardiff in 2004 and has since been involved in the business. He plays a pivotal role in the functioning of the company and is responsible for production, procurement and Quality Control. In addition, he also oversees sales within India and a few key markets abroad.

Sudhanshu brings in a youthful vigor and can-do attitude to the business and has implemented multiple processes and systems that help scale up productivity and operational efficiency without compromising on quality.

  1. Decoding Basmati Rice

    Basmati is one of the most popular types of rice globally and is produced in the Indo-Gangetic plains of India. It stands out for its distinctive, approved natural fragrance. The grain itself is slender and long and grows up to 2.5x its size after cooking, adiposity resulting in a fluffy and soft avatar. It offers a heady aroma, store easily distinguishable signature flavor and unmatched taste. The word Basmati is primarily attained from the Sanskrit word vasmati which translates into fragrant. Basmati rice is thought to have been grown and cultivated in the Indian subcontinent for centuries and is used in several signature Indian & Middle-eastern dishes. The rice gets its signature characteristics on account of several factors including harvesting methods, agro-climatic circumstances during cultivation, aging and processing. Read More

  2. Nutritional Facts

    There are several key nutritional facts that you need to be aware of while consuming Basmati rice. We have witnessed several views and reviews on Basmati rice including assessments of its quality, discount nutrients, medical calories and more. Here’s giving you an illuminating and informative idea of the same. Read More

Cooking it right

Cooking it right

If cooked right, Basmati should be soft and fluffy with long slender grains and a distinct aroma

Open Pan Method

Open Pan (or excess water) is where rice is cooked in lots of water just like potatoes or pasta, then drained in a colander. Bring a large pan of water to the boil. Add 1/2 to 1 teaspoon of salt (optional). When boiling, tip in 250g/300ml (for 4 servings) of rice. Return the water to the boil then stir well. Lower the heat to a fast simmer and cook according to the variety. Drain in a colander and allow to stand for 5 minutes before fluffing with a fork and adding a little butter or oil (optional).

Using rice cookers

Many of us prefer using rice cookers for saving time and energy while cooking Basmati rice. These rice cookers are electrically operated and independent cooking devices for rice. Cooking times with rice cookers are quite similar to those generated out of the covered pan method for Basmati rice. You have to put in rice and water in carefully measured quantities into the rice cooker which you have to cover and switch on. Upon the absorption of water completely by the rice, the cooker will automatically turn off. You can also forget your worries about the rice staying warm and soft as the cooker itself will accomplish this task for quite a few hours at least.

Covered Pan Method

Covered Pan (or absorption) is where the rice is cooked with a measured amount of water in a covered pan. The rice absorbs the water completely and is not drained. Place 250g/300ml (for 4 servings) of rice in a medium pan. Measure in cold water (1 measure dry rice : 2 measures water). The water to rice ratio can be altered to obtain the required rice texture. Add to 1 teaspoon salt (optional). Bring to the boil, stir then cover and turn the heat to ‘low’. Cooking time depends on the grain Read More…

Combined Technique

There is a special combined technique that you can use while cooking Basmati rice along with several other specialized dishes simultaneously. Rice in this method is usually cooked on the basis of the open pan method but cooking times are lower than the original. You have to drain and rinse the rice with cold water, drain the same once again and put it directly into the fridge in a covered container for microwave ovens till it has to be served. Simply reheat the same on a high power mode before serving and this will take only a few minutes.

Microwave based method

Some of us simply love anything to do with microwave ovens as they save us oodles of time and energy while cooking. You can even cook Basmati rice with your microwave oven though regular cooking methods are also possible in near about the same duration. However, washing and draining are kept out of the equation by microwave ovens. Cooking times will differ as per the power capabilities and outputs of your microwave oven. You do not need to stir or move Read More…

Oven Baking

Oven baking is one process which takes up a whole lot of time and most of us do not use ovens here in India. But for those who do, this is quite satisfactory and fulfilling in the end owing to the ability to prepare specialized pudding rice or while a casserole is being baked in the oven. Quantities of water are almost identical to volumes needed in the covered pan method. You have to use boiling water and rice and stir the same before covering and baking at 180 degrees. This method takes around 25-35 minutes on an average when it comes to white Basmati rice.

The Parakh range contains everything for culinary enthusiasts! From regal enticement to daily excellence, you’ll find the perfect rice variety for you here at United Exports. We value quality above all else and have a stringent and immaculate manufacturing process for all our varieties and brands.

Know more about our Products

Have Queries?

Read Our Frequently Asked Questions

Why Rinse and Soak Basmati Rice?

Soaking and rinsing are not imperative in case of Basmati rice. However, these two processes do contribute towards an overall lightening of the grain. You can have soaking times ranging between 5 and 30 minutes on an average. In case of longer soaking times, cooking times are directly scaled down and this helps immensely in case of paucity of time or if you have too many things to make at once. Read More…

Storage Aspects

Rice has always been stored up by several civilizations over the years as offerings for the gods and nourishment for human beings. You should try to store Basmati rice in an area which is cool, dry and clean. Read More…

Special attributes of Basmati Rice

Many people do not know that Ayurveda, one of our most ancient and scientific disciplines recommends the consumption of Basmati rice as opposed to all other rice types. This may come across as pretty surprising to those not in the loop.Read More…

Latent USPs of Basmati Rice

Basmati Rice has several USPs that you should definitely keep in mind! It offers multifarious health benefits to consumers. Firstly, Basmati rice is not as sticky as other rice varieties and is mostly used for biryani, casseroles, rice pilafs and curries owing to its fluffy and soft texture. The white and brown varieties of Basmati rice are both long grain rice and are usually grown in both Pakistan and India only. Read More…
